name: Creative Minds
description: Insights on creativity and innovation from artists, writers, and inventors.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: Imagination is more important than knowledge. Knowledge is limited. Imagination encircles the world.
quotes.notes: From an interview with George Sylvester Viereck titled 'What Life Means to Einstein.' This is the verified full quote; shorter versions often circulate.

quotes.content: Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Picasso. The sentiment appears in various biographies though the exact original context is difficult to verify.

quotes.content: Creativity takes courage.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Matisse and consistent with his philosophy of bold artistic expression. Exact source unverified.

quotes.content: The chief enemy of creativity is good sense.
quotes.notes: Attributed to Picasso. Reflects his rebellious approach to artistic convention and willingness to break rules.

quotes.content: You can't use up creativity. The more you use, the more you have.
quotes.notes: From an interview. Angelou frequently discussed creativity as an inexhaustible resource in her lectures and writings.

quotes.content: To be creative means to be in love with life.
quotes.notes: From Osho's book on creativity. Originally from his discourses on living creatively.

quotes.content: The desire to create is one of the deepest yearnings of the human soul.
quotes.notes: From Uchtdorf's LDS General Conference talk 'Happiness, Your Heritage.' Verified from official church records.

quotes.content: Imagination is the beginning of creation. You imagine what you desire, you will what you imagine, and at last, you create what you will.
quotes.notes: From Shaw's play 'Back to Methuselah.' The full passage describes the creative process in sequence.

quotes.content: Art is not what you see, but what you make others see.
quotes.notes: Attributed to French Impressionist Edgar Degas. Reflects his philosophy that art is about perception and communication.

quotes.content: Creativity is intelligence having fun.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Einstein but no verified source exists. The sentiment aligns with his playful approach to science and thought experiments.

quotes.content: The painter has the Universe in his mind and hands.
quotes.notes: From Leonardo's collected writings on painting, compiled after his death. Original Italian: 'Il pittore ha l'universo nella sua mente e nelle sue mani.'

quotes.content: There is no must in art because art is free.
quotes.notes: From Kandinsky's influential theoretical text on abstract art and the spiritual purpose of artistic creation.

quotes.content: The artist is nothing without the gift, but the gift is nothing without work.
quotes.notes: Attributed to French author Emile Zola. Reflects his naturalist philosophy balancing talent with discipline.

quotes.content: I dream my painting and I paint my dream.
quotes.notes: From Van Gogh's extensive correspondence with his brother Theo. Describes his intuitive creative process.

quotes.content: Learn the rules like a pro, so you can break them like an artist.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Picasso though unverified. Reflects his journey from classical training to revolutionary modernism.

quotes.content: Have no fear of perfection - you'll never reach it.
quotes.notes: Attributed to Dali and consistent with his surrealist embrace of imperfection and the unexpected.

quotes.content: The creative adult is the child who survived.
quotes.notes: Attributed to the science fiction author. Reflects her views on imagination and the importance of preserving childlike wonder.

quotes.content: I begin with an idea, and then it becomes something else.
quotes.notes: From various interviews with Picasso about his creative process. Describes how his works evolved organically.

quotes.content: If you hear a voice within you say 'you cannot paint,' then by all means paint, and that voice will be silenced.
quotes.notes: Verified from Van Gogh's letters. Advice about overcoming self-doubt through persistent creative action.

quotes.content: The worst enemy to creativity is self-doubt.
quotes.source: The Unabridged Journals of Sylvia Plath (1950-1962, published 2000)
quotes.notes: From Plath's personal journals. Reflects her struggles with perfectionism and creative blocks.

quotes.content: To practice any art, no matter how well or badly, is a way to make your soul grow.
quotes.notes: From Vonnegut's collection of essays. He encourages creating for its own sake rather than for recognition.

quotes.content: Art enables us to find ourselves and lose ourselves at the same time.
quotes.notes: From Merton's book on spiritual life. The Trappist monk saw art as a form of contemplation.

quotes.content: Inspiration exists, but it has to find you working.
quotes.notes: One of Picasso's most famous quotes about the creative process. Emphasizes discipline over waiting for inspiration.

quotes.content: I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free.
quotes.notes: Frequently attributed to Michelangelo regarding his sculpture process. No contemporary source, but consistent with Renaissance artistic philosophy.

quotes.content: Great things are done by a series of small things brought together.
quotes.notes: Verified from Van Gogh's correspondence. Advice about breaking large creative projects into manageable steps.

quotes.content: The true sign of intelligence is not knowledge but imagination.
quotes.notes: Commonly attributed to Einstein. Aligns with his emphasis on thought experiments and creative thinking in physics.

quotes.content: Art is the lie that enables us to realize the truth.
quotes.notes: From an interview in The Arts magazine. One of Picasso's most philosophical statements about artistic representation.

quotes.content: Everything you can imagine is real.
quotes.notes: Widely attributed to Picasso. Reflects his surrealist connections and belief in the reality of imaginative experience.

quotes.content: A creative man is motivated by the desire to achieve, not by the desire to beat others.
quotes.notes: From Rand's novel about architect Howard Roark. Reflects her philosophy of individual creative achievement.

quotes.content: The object of art is not to reproduce reality, but to create a reality of the same intensity.
quotes.notes: Attributed to the Swiss sculptor. Reflects his approach to creating art that captures emotional rather than literal truth.
